title: 107_hr5558
content: The "Retirement Savings and Security Act of 2002" may accelerate increases in IRA contribution limits. The "Retirement Savings and Security Act of 2002" accelerates increases in IRA contribution limits, with the deductible amount set at $5,000 and a catch-up contribution of $1,000 for individuals 50 or older. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 3. ACCELERATION OF SCHEDULED INCREASES IN PENSION PLAN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase contribution limits for elective deferrals, deferred compensation plans, simple retirement accounts, and catch-up contributions. The new limits are $15,000 for elective deferrals, $15,000 for deferred compensation plans, $10,000 for simple retirement accounts, $5,000 for catch-up contributions in clause (i), and $2,500 for catch-up contributions in clause (ii). The amendments made by this section increase contribution limits for various retirement accounts, with catch-up contributions capped at $2,500. Effective Date: Applies to years starting after December 31, 2002. SEC. 4. SIMPLIFICATION AND UPDATING OF THE MINIMUM DISTRIBUTION RULES. Required distributions will now be determined by the applicable age instead of age 70\1/2\. The minimum distribution rules have been updated to be determined by the applicable age instead of age 70\1/2\. Spouse beneficiaries and actuarial adjustments under defined benefit plans are also affected by these changes. The accrued benefit will be increased to account for the period after the employee turns 70\1/2\, and the effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2002. The amendments made after December 31, 2002, ensure that distributions to employees meet the requirements of section 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
